To make the results as comparable as possible to the earlier literature we restrict the sample to stayers - workers employed the two entire and consecutive years in the same firm, and we define wages that stay constant as those that change less than 0.5% [see Kurmann and McEntarfer, 2017]. We pool all year-to-year wage changes over the period 1999-2013. During the period of interest, we document substantial microeconomic evidence of downward nominal wage rigidity. Nominal wage cuts are rare, even in low-growth years or in regions facing downturns.

Figure A2 shows the kernel density of the pooled distribution of wage changes.58 We find that 16.0 percent of wages fall from one year to the next, 2.7 percent stay constant, and 81.3 percent rise.59 For comparison, Kurmann et al. [2016]] report that 30 percent of hourly wages fall in the U.S. private sector in a 30-state sample during 1999-2011.

Figures A3a and A3b show that the distribution of wage changes is similar for skilled and unskilled individuals, as well as across sectors.60 Additionally we document that the asymmetry in the distribution and the small frequency of nominal wage cuts holds in both high and low growth years, as figure A3c shows. We also classify region-year pairs into quartiles according to the intensity of regional commodity price shocks. As figure A3d shows, there is very little impact of these price shocks on the asymmetry of the wage change distribution and on its left tail. Macroeconomic evidence. In addition to the micro-level results, we find macroeconomic evidence of downward nominal wage rigidity. Following Schmitt-GroheÃÅÃÂ and Uribe [2016] we examine the path of aggregate wages in a context of rising unemployment, relatively low inflation, and a crawling peg of the Brazilian Real to the U.S. dollar during the period 1996 - 1998 (immediately prior to the 1999 devaluation). Under a cumulative 29% increase in the unemployment rate, nominal wages rose slightly and real wages were practically flat. In contrast, in a flexible labor market, one would expect a decline in nominal wages. As Schmitt-GroheÃÅÃÂ and Uribe [2016] (who study a similar episode in Argentina) point out, this is highly indicative of downward nominal wage rigidity. In fact it was only following the 1999 devaluation that real wages (in dollar terms) fell.
